DOC.HEAD: Exiles See Brighter Future for Romania
With AM-US-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: One exiled Romanian dissident said Friday that Nicolae Ceausescu had ``lost touch with reality,'' while another said he was ready to return to help shape his country's future. ``I am ready to assume my responsibility and to save my people,'' Mihai Botez said in an interview from New York City. Botez, a mathematician and economic planner exiled by Ceausescu in 1987, said all political scenarios are open for Romania's future, but one model is ``over, and that's Stalinism. A former economic adviser to the Romanian government before he fell out of favor 10 years before his exile, Botez said he would like to see the country develop a strong private sector, ``although some socialist, nationalized enterprises will remain at first.'' Vladimir Tismaneanu, a resident scholar at the Foreign Policy Research Institute in Philadelphia, said that when Ceausescu ordered troops to fire on anti-government protesters last week, it was ``a clear indication that Ceausescu had completely lost touch with reality.'' Ceausescu's cult of personality and ``megalomania'' during his 24-year reign were compounded by his wife Elena's ``idiosyncracies,'' Tismaneanu said. Corneliu Manescu, the 73-year-old former foreign minister who assumed leadership of a provisional government in Romania after Ceausescu fled, is ill and will probably only serve as a transitional leader until free elections are held, Tismaneanu said. But Ion Iliescu, a former Central Committee secretary ousted by Ceausescu in 1971, would likely play a major role in the new order in Romania, he said. Iliescu, who announced Friday that a ``National Salvation Front'' had been set up to rule the country, was a classmate of Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev at Moscow State University in the 1950s, Tismaneanu said. Botez, who has been a guest scholar at several U.S. think tanks and universities since his departure from Romania was achieved with the help of the State Department, says he has not been able to contact his wife since he left Romania. His wife, also a prominent dissident, has been under house arrest, as he was for several months before leaving Romania. The first priority, Botez said, is to supply food and clothing to Romanians ``and stop the desperate suffering.'' The foreign ministers of the European Community pledged immediate aid to Romania on Friday and the International Committee for the Red Cross dispatched two planes carrying 4 tons of medical supplies to Bucharest.
